noun.description: An act or movement of putting one leg in front of the other in walking or running.
examples: she turned and retraced her steps

noun.description: A flat surface, especially one in a series, on which to place one's foot when moving from one level to another.
examples: the bottom step of the staircase

noun.description: A measure or action, especially one of a series taken in order to deal with or achieve a particular thing.
examples: the government must take steps to discourage age discrimination
a major step forward in the fight for justice

noun.description: An interval in a scale; a tone (whole step) or semitone (half step).
An abrupt change in the value of a quantity, especially voltage.
A block, typically fixed to the vessel's keel, on which the base of a mast is seated.

verb.description: Lift and set down one's foot or one foot after the other in order to walk somewhere or move to a new position.
examples: I accidentally stepped on his foot

verb.description: Set up (a mast) in its step.

phrases: Neither of them broke step as they walked with their heads up but eyes down.
Then they break step and disperse over Southwark Bridge, chatting and slouching.
They were all of different heights and strides yet they never broke step.
Passers-by in this northern suburb in the foothills of Iran's Elborz Mountains are few, and most walk past without breaking step.
Interested, I fell into step behind them as they walked.
he has stepped aside as adviser to both firms
He couldn't help stepping back and looking at the absurdity of his situation.
Over at The Globe and Mail, Kate Taylor steps back and takes a look at the book reviewing debate.
It's about time somebody took a few steps back and realised what country is.
Not once did he step back to draw together various pieces and put them into a single theory.
origin: Old English stæpe, stepe (noun), stæppan, steppan (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch steppen and German stapfen.
